title: Jane Fonda vows to ‘get arrested every Friday’ for the climate crisis
text:
Jane Fonda has promised to use her celebrity status to raise awareness for the climate emergency (Picture: CNN; AP)

Jane Fonda has vowed to use her celebrity status to draw attention to the climate crisis by getting herself arrested ‘every Friday’.

The actor and activist, 82, was arrested in Washington DC last week while taking part in a climate change protest, but has promised to keep going until the people in power take urgent action in the climate emergency.

She explained why she ended up being handcuffed last week: ‘: I can tell you exactly, it was Labor Day weekend and I was reading Naomi Klein’s new book called On Fire: The Burning Case for a Green New Deal and I was hearing the Greta Thunberg, the Swedish climate striker and it really hit me how urgent this issue is and that I wasn’t doing enough.

‘You know, I drive an electric car, I recycle, I’ve gotten rid of plastics. But that’s a good starting place, it’s not a good finishing place,’ she told CNN’s Christiane Amanpour.

‘This is a collective crisis. It requires collective action. And so, I decided to use my celebrity to try to raise the sense of urgency and I moved to Washington and I’m going to get arrested every Friday.’

Jane was one of 16 people who were charged with ‘crowding, obstructing or incommoding’, but told fans on her website that she will be back every week until something is done.

She wrote: ‘I will be on the Capitol every Friday, rain or shine, inspired and emboldened by the incredible movement our youth have created.

Jane Fonda has been an activist since the 1960s (Picture: AP)

‘I can no longer stand by and let our elected officials ignore – and even worse – empower – the industries that are destroying our planet for profit. We can not continue to stand for this.’

She and her fellow activists were held for a few hours in a police cell, before each paying $50 (£39.60) to be released.

Jane admitted that the plastic handcuffs hurt her wrists and that it was difficult for her to get in and out of the police van without her hands.

She wrote: ‘White plastic ‘handcuffs’ were put on each of us, we were taken to the nearby police station for a few hours.

‘The plastic handcuffs hurt more than the metal ones and I discovered that it’s not easy for an 82-year-old to get in and out of a police [van] without the use of her hands. All the police women and men were super polite and nice.’

Jane has a long history of political activism, beginning in the 1960s when she supported the Civil Rights Movement and opposed the Vietnam war.
